intro: Tagetes erythrocephala, commonly known as the red-headed marigold, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its vibrant orange to red flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces showy, tubular inflorescences that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are sturdy and branching. Tagetes erythrocephala is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory properties.
